snippet: After 21 years, 93 cases and $2 billion, the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, established to pursue justice in the 1994 genocide that claimed nearly one million people, is closing down.
abstract: International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda hears its final cases; court, based in Tanzania, was created by United Nations in 1994 to try organizers of Rwandan genocide which killed almost one million people; prosecutions of eight remaining suspects at large, and any other unfinished business, will be handled by smaller court in The Hague.

byline.contributor: Jeffrey Gettleman contributed reporting from Nairobi, Kenya.

lead_paragraph: After 21 years, 93 cases and $2 billion, the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, established to pursue justice in the 1994 genocide that claimed nearly one million people, is closing down.

headline.main: Last Days for U.N. Court Trying Suspects in Rwanda Genocide
headline.print_headline: Special U.N. Court on Rwandan Genocide Closes Its Doors After 21 Years

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
